description: From Middle English jupartie, jeopardie (“even chance”), from Old French jeu parti (“a divided game, i.e. an even game, an even chance”), from Medieval Latin iocus partītus (“an even chance, an alternative”), from Latin iocus (“jest, play, game”) + partītus, perfect passive participle of partiō (“divide”); see joke and party.

entries.meaning: Danger of loss, harm, or failure.
examples: The poor condition of the vehicle put its occupants in constant jeopardy.

verbs.description: jeopardy (third-person singular simple present jeopardies, present participle jeopardying, simple past and past participle jeopardied)
